byline.original: By DECLAN WALSH, BEN HUBBARD and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: Declan Walsh reported from Cairo, Ben Hubbard from Beirut, Lebanon, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Carlotta Gall contributed reporting from Pristina, Kosovo, and Suliman Ali Zway from Tripoli, Libya.

lead_paragraph: The strikes, which Western officials said targeted a senior operative linked to attacks in Tunisia, highlighted a growing gap in American military and diplomatic efforts.

headline.print_headline: U.S. Bombing in Libya Reveals Strategy’s Limits
headline.main: U.S. Bombing in Libya Reveals Limits of Strategy Against ISIS

snippet: The strikes, which Western officials said targeted a senior operative linked to attacks in Tunisia, highlighted a growing gap in American military and diplomatic efforts.
abstract: American warplanes bomb Libya with hopes of killing Tunisian militant linked to attacks on Western tourists in 2015; airstrikes underscore United States’ growing concern about rise of Islamic State and about limitations of American strategies, both diplomatic and military, in countries where group is strongest.
